docs.snippet: BARBER B. CONABLE JR., president of the World Bank, flew 16 hours each way to Punta del Este, Uruguay, in October, to give a 10-minute speech.   Why? To propagate the faith that open trade is essential for the economic growth and debt management of...
docs.lead_paragraph: BARBER B. CONABLE JR., president of the World Bank, flew 16 hours each way to Punta del Este, Uruguay, in October, to give a 10-minute speech. Why? To propagate the faith that open trade is essential for the economic growth and debt management of developing nations. ''I wanted trade ministers to understand the necessity of keeping trade open,'' he said in a recent interview. Mr. Conable attended the now-celebrated meeting that set the agenda for new trade liberalization, called the Uruguay Round.

docs.snippet: The United States plans to end its three-year-old ban on imports of Soviet nickel, and both Washington and Moscow will intensify efforts to help American companies obtain more Soviet business, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.   The...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States plans to end its three-year-old ban on imports of Soviet nickel, and both Washington and Moscow will intensify efforts to help American companies obtain more Soviet business, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today. The announcement of improving commercial relations between the two countries came after a meeting here this week of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Joint Commercial Commission, a body set up by the two Governments during a thaw in relations in 1972. The Soviet Foreign Trade Minister, Boris I. Aristov, who headed the Soviet delegation, said at a news conference that ''we would like to increase trade three and four times with you.'' He described trade as ''one of the oldest professions'' and the sector ''where confidence between our two nations can be achieved easier than in other fields.''

headline.main: U.S. TO END ITS SOVIET NICKEL BAN

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: IN the election campaign here last month, the tiny pro-Albanian Communist Party of Brazil mobilized its activists, waved its red flags and violated a good many Marxist-Leninist precepts in supporting Wellington Moreira Franco, the nominee of a...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the election campaign here last month, the tiny pro-Albanian Communist Party of Brazil mobilized its activists, waved its red flags and violated a good many Marxist-Leninist precepts in supporting Wellington Moreira Franco, the nominee of a right-of-center coalition. When he won, defeating two candidates long identified with socialist causes, the party was able to claim victory. It was a triumph of opportunism over ideology. In the gubernatorial and Congressional elections held here and throughout Brazil Nov. 15, the left in fact took a beating. Only where it joined forces with more conservative parties did it fare reasonably well - and even then Communists won just five seats in the new 487-member Congress. Otherwise, the left's radical message was generally ignored. The pro-Moscow Brazilian Communist Party now even regrets that it chose to ''go public'' as a legal party last year.

headline.main: THE LATIN LEFT IS FREE TO BE UNPOPULAR

docs.snippet: Using such innocuous instruments as trade in onions and carrots, as well as more sophisticated exchanges on nuclear energy and biotechnology, Brazil and Argentina have begun burying their political rivalry and assuming the challenge of integrating...
docs.lead_paragraph: Using such innocuous instruments as trade in onions and carrots, as well as more sophisticated exchanges on nuclear energy and biotechnology, Brazil and Argentina have begun burying their political rivalry and assuming the challenge of integrating their economies. The moves, which gained momentum during a three-day visit here this week by President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina, have been compared to the postwar reconciliation of France and West Germany that established the political basis for creation of the European Community. ''We know that we are taking steps that are historically decisive,'' President Jose Sarney of Brazil said Wednesday. ''We cannot conceive the future of Brazil without a mutually beneficial friendship with Argentina.''

headline.main: FOR BRAZIL AND ARGENTINA, NEW AMITY

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: For nearly a century, Santa Fe has attracted artists with its old adobes, turquoise skies and special feeling of space and light. Early Santa Fe paintings depict sunlight sharply slanting off adobe walls and winter snow. For admirers of strong...
docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly a century, Santa Fe has attracted artists with its old adobes, turquoise skies and special feeling of space and light. Early Santa Fe paintings depict sunlight sharply slanting off adobe walls and winter snow. For admirers of strong contrasts and color, Canyon Road - the city's gallery row - remains a special delight in winter: red dirt, brown adobe, white snow and a late-afternoon violet wash over all. Among the earliest artists to arrive on the road before World War I were Gerald Cassidy and Sheldon Parsons. In poor health, they came for New Mexico's curative mountain air and stayed to paint the strong light created by the blue desert sky and the bright sun. Mr. Cassidy bought an old adobe, salvaging beams from an abandoned 17th-century mission to repair a burned-out roof. Other artists followed: Fremont Ellis, John Sloane, and Randall Davey lived on Canyon and nearby Camino del Monte Sol from the 1920's on.

byline.original: By STEPHEN LEWIS; Stephen Lewis is a writer who lives in Santa Fe, N.M

docs.snippet: Eight Latin American Governments have announced that the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to join them in a new initiative aimed at reviving peace negotiations in Central America.   A...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight Latin American Governments have announced that the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States had agreed to join them in a new initiative aimed at reviving peace negotiations in Central America. A special delegation is expected to visit the capitals of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica in January in the hope of persuading the five Central American Governments to return to the bargaining table. The delegation will include the heads of the two international organizations and the foreign ministers of the eight countries organizing the effort.

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: After an all-night debate that was interrupted by fistfights, the House of Deputies today overwhelmingly approved an amnesty for soldiers accused of human rights violations during the 1973-85 military rule.   President Julio Sanguinetti promptly...
docs.lead_paragraph: After an all-night debate that was interrupted by fistfights, the House of Deputies today overwhelmingly approved an amnesty for soldiers accused of human rights violations during the 1973-85 military rule. President Julio Sanguinetti promptly signed the bill into law. The Senate approved the amnesty Sunday, and the House's 60-to-37 vote averted a showdown between the armed forces and the 21-month-old elected Government. During its 12 years in power, the military jailed tens of thousands of people and tortured many of them as part of a crackdown on the left.

docs.snippet: The Argentine Congress adopted legislation tonight that is expected to bring an end to the prosecution of military officers accused of murder, torture, kidnapping and other crimes during the late 1970's and early 1980's.   Crowds of demonstrators...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Argentine Congress adopted legislation tonight that is expected to bring an end to the prosecution of military officers accused of murder, torture, kidnapping and other crimes during the late 1970's and early 1980's. Crowds of demonstrators opposed to the bill gathered outside the Congress as the voting occurred just before midnight, and riot policemen filled the surrounding streets to assure safe exit for members of the Chamber of Deputies. Earlier in the evening, the majority leader of the Chamber, Cesar Jaroslavsky, was struck by demonstrators when he went outside briefly. The law establishes a period of 60 days for the continued filing of charges, but after that ''penal action will be extinguished'' on cases arising from the so-called ''dirty war'' against leftists. It was drafted under pressure from military leaders, who have argued that their actions during that era had ample public support.

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The start of a new effort to revive peace negotiations in Central American was announced last week by eight Latin American governments, who said the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States would join them.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The start of a new effort to revive peace negotiations in Central American was announced last week by eight Latin American governments, who said the Secretaries General of the United Nations and the Organization of American States would join them. The initiative was announced after a meeting in Rio de Janiero of the four members of the so-called Contadora group - Venezuela, Colombia, Mexico and Panama - and four nations supporting the negotiation effort - Brazil, Argentina, Peru and Uruguay.

headline.main: New Peace Move In Central America

byline.original: By Katherine Roberts, Milt Freudenheim and James F. Clarity

docs.snippet: THERE were noisy, emotional and sometimes violent reactions last week to the enactment of a law that will largely halt prosecutions of Argentine military officers accused of human rights violations.   But more notable, perhaps, was the indifference...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE were noisy, emotional and sometimes violent reactions last week to the enactment of a law that will largely halt prosecutions of Argentine military officers accused of human rights violations. But more notable, perhaps, was the indifference with which the law was greeted by most Argentines. They were concerned about Christmas and departures to the beach or countryside, so the opposition was left primarily to human rights groups and several small leftist political parties. Some observers here said this may indicate that many Argentines agreed with the military's argument that all share a burden for the excesses of an era in which doctors did not denounce torture, lawyers were afraid to file habeas corpus petitions, the Roman Catholic hierarchy was silent and the dominant newspapers generally took safe positions.

headline.main: ARGENTINA AND URUGUAY PARDON SOME OLD ABUSES
